<link>http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/10/edible-landscapes-workshop-flyer.html</link> <description>You need to see this beautiful flyer and learn about Edible Landscapes! Click to see Barbara Newton EL Workshop flyer</description> <content:encoded><p><strong><span style="font-size: 13pt; color: #ff0000;">You need to see this beautiful flyer and learn about Edible Landscapes!</span></strong></p> <p>&#0160;<span class="asset  asset-generic at-xid-6a00d83420bb4d53ef017c326bf325970b"><a href="http://gv.typepad.com/files/barbara-newton-el-workshop-flyer.pdf">Click to see Barbara Newton EL Workshop flyer</a></span></p> <p>&#0160;</p> <p><span class="asset  asset-generic at-xid-6a00d83420bb4d53ef017c326bf325970b"><br /></span></p></content:encoded>    <dc:creator>Gunpowder</dc:creator> <dc:date>2012-10-09T15:35:46-04:00</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/09/ncr-trail-map.html"> <title>NCR Trail Map</title> <link>http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/09/ncr-trail-map.html</link> <description>GUNPOWDER FALLS STATE PARK NORTHERN CENTRAL RAILROAD TRAIL HISTORY: For 134 years, from 1838 to 1972, the Northern Central Railroad connected Baltimore with York PA, encouraging the growth of small towns such as Ashland, Phoenix, Sparks, Glencoe, Corbett, Monkton, White...</description> <content:encoded><a class="asset-img-link" href="http://gv.typepad.com/.a/6a00d83420bb4d53ef017d3c61dbe8970c-pi" style="display: inline;"><img alt="NCR TrailMap Vert" border="0" class="asset  asset-image at-xid-6a00d83420bb4d53ef017d3c61dbe8970c image-full" src="http://gv.typepad.com/.a/6a00d83420bb4d53ef017d3c61dbe8970c-800wi" title="NCR TrailMap Vert" /></a><br /><br /> <h1>GUNPOWDER FALLS STATE PARK NORTHERN CENTRAL RAILROAD TRAIL</h1> <p><strong>HISTORY</strong>: For 134 years, from 1838 to 1972, the Northern Central Railroad connected Baltimore with York PA, encouraging the growth of small towns such as Ashland, Phoenix, Sparks, Glencoe, Corbett, Monkton, White Hall, Parkton, Bentley Springs, and Freeland. The railroad was a major link in the exchange of goods between these rural communities and the City of Baltimore. These included flour, paper, milk and farm products, coal, and .later the U.S. Mail. </p> <p>During the Civil War, hundreds of-Union soldiers were transported south on the railroad. Abraham Lincoln traveled on the Northern Central on his way to deliver his famous Gettysburg Address, and later his body would be transported to Harrisburg via these same rails after his assassination. <br /> Increasing truck and automobile transportation marked the decline 9f the railroad, and in 1972 Hurricane Agnes washed out bridges and made the line impassable .. In 1984, DNR converted the abandoned right- of-way into &#39;a multi-use trail. </p> <p><strong>FEATURES</strong>: The Northern Central Railroad Trail is over 19 miles long and runs from Ashland to the Maryland State LineThe trail is a l0-foot-wide crushed stone surface laid on a level railroad bed. Restrooms are available at Paper Mill, Phoenix, Glencoe, Monkton, White Hall, Bentley Springs, and Freeland. Water is available at Sparks, Monkton, and White Hall.</p> <p><strong>ACTIVITIES</strong>:, The most popular activities on the trail are hiking, jogging, bicycleriding, and horseback riding. The trail also provides&#39; access for fishing on the Loch Raven watershed and over eight miles of managed trout stream &#39;onthe Big Gunpowder River and the Little. Falls. </p> <p><strong>REGULATIONS</strong>: Park regulations are posted at the parking lots and road crossings. Alcoholic beverages, camping, fires, weapons, and motorized vehicles are prohibited at all times. All pets must be leashed when on the trail, Users should stay on the &#39;trail, as the land on both sides is privately owned. </p> <p>All Maryland State Parks are now 1RASH FREE. Trail users are required to remove their own trash when leaving the area. Small trash bags are available at Monkton, White Hall and Freeland. <br /> For a safe and enjoyable visit to the NCR Trail the following rules of the road are encouraged:</p> <p>Bicyclist - Ride to the right. &#39; Watch your speed, Pedestrian/equestrians have the right of way. Bell or horn is required on all bicycles. Give audible signal before passing other cyclists and pedestrians. Obey all traffic signs. </p> <p>Pedestrian - Walk/jog to the right. Yield to horses. Avoid walking two or three abreast and blocking the trail. Pets must be leashed and under the owner&#39;s control.</p> <p>Horseback Rider - Ride to the right. Let, pedestrians/cyclists know when it is safe to pass. Be aware of other users. (Note: Horse trailer parking available at Paper Mill Road, Sparks, White Hall, Bentley Springs and Freeland.) </p> <p><strong>PARKING</strong>: &#0160;</p> <p>Ashland - Take Route 45 (York Road) to&#39; Cockeysville. Turn east on Ashland Road for one-half mile to dead end at , parking lot. Do not bear left on Paper Mill Road. </p> <p>Paper Mill Road - Take Route 45 (York Road) to Cockeysville. Turn east 0)1 Ashland Road for .4 mile, Ashland Road becomes Paper Mill Road. Parking available on shoulders of the roadway.</p> <p>Phoenix - Take Phoenix Road east from route 45 (York Road) and follow for 1.7 miles to parking lot. An alternative route is to take Paper Mill Road to Phoenix: Road, before the Hunt Valley Golf Course. Follow 1 mile to parking lot.</p> <p>Sparks - Take Route 45 (York Road) and tum east on Sparks Road proceeding .7 of a mile to the parking lot.</p> <p>Monkton - Take Monkton Road east from Route 45 (York Road). Follow 3 miles to trail crossing and the parking lot is in the town of Monkton. From Route 152 (Mountain Road) take Hess Road west, across Jarrettsville Pike to Monkton Road. Turn right, and follow Monkton Road 2.3 miles to parking lot. Parking is. very limited at this lot. Users are encouraged &#39;to park in other areas.</p> <p>White Hall - Take Route 45 (York Road) and tum east on Weisburg Road. Follow Weisburg Road for 2 miles. Parking lot is at Weisburg and White Hall Roads. </p> <p>Parkton- Take Route 4S (York Road) to Parkton. Turn west on to Frederick Road and park at 18858 Frederick Road.</p> <p>Bentley Springs - Take Route 45, (York Road) and tum left on Kaufman Road. Follow Kaufman Road for about .7 of a mile and turn left onto Bentley Road and proceed to the parking lot. Tum west on Bentley Road off of Route 45 (York Road) and proceed 1.8 miles to the parking lot. </p> <p>Freeland - Take Route 45 (York Road) and tum west on to Freeland Road. Follow for 2 miles to&#39; the parking lot.</p> <p><strong>TO OBTAIN ADDITIONAL INFORMATION, PLEASE SEND A SELF-ADDRESSED, STAMPED ENVELOPE WITH YOUR REQUEST, OR CALL: </strong></p> <p>Gunpowder Falls State Park&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160; Phone (410) 592-2897<br /> PO Box 5032&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160; <br /> Glan Arm, MD 21057&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160;&#0160; DNR TTY for Deaf: (410) 974-3683</p> <p><strong>TO REPORT AN EMERGENCY OR LAW VIOLATION, CONTACT</strong>: </p> <p>Longhill Communication Center: (800) 825\ufffd\ufffd7275 24-hours. Your name will be kept confidential. ,Pay phones are located on the trail at Paper Mill Road, Phoenix, Sparks, Monkton, White Hall, Bentley Springs and Freeland.&#0160;</p></content:encoded>    <dc:creator>Gunpowder</dc:creator> <dc:date>2012-09-28T16:15:38-04:00</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/09/summer-membership-appreciation-canoe-trip.html"> <title>Summer Membership Appreciation Canoe Trip</title> <link>http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/09/summer-membership-appreciation-canoe-trip.html</link> <description>Click HERE to see a slide show of the trip On Saturday, August 18th, thirty-five GVC members ventured forth with canoes, paddles, life vests and plenty of daring-do. The weather was perfect; low humidity, blue sky, big clouds. We began...</description> <content:encoded><p style="text-align: center;">Click <a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/alpeabody/sets/72157631454792038/show/" target="_self" title="2012 Canoe Trip Slide Show">HERE</a> to see a slide show of the trip</p> <p>On Saturday, August 18th, thirty-five GVC members ventured forth with canoes, paddles, life vests and plenty of daring-do. The weather was perfect; low humidity, blue sky, big clouds. We began our trip at Stan Dorman\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds farm, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdRiver Bend.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Led by our veteran instructors, Gene Flanagan and Winny Tan from Oregon Ridge Nature Center, we paddled down the glorious and serene river. The sounds and sights were a sensory delight; lush riverside forests with chattery birds; shallow pools and fast riffles among boulders and rocks. Our destination was three miles down the river, at the Northern Central Railroad Trail (Torrey C. Brown Rail Trail) in Phoenix.</p> <p>Some of us leisurely took in the sights, while others came on a mission \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd to fish out abandoned tires. It seemed odd so many tires made their way into the river, here in the rural part of the county, but there they lurked, abundant! GVC members fished out 24 tires. The trip went well overall, though the river was fairly shallow in some spots, requiring some deft paddling! The members of the GVC enjoyed an amazing canoe trip down the Gunpowder River, and the adventure was concluded with a tasty repast donated by Graul\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Market in Hereford, MD.</p> <p>When we returned to River Bend, we were greeted by an inviting setting of chairs and picnic tables set around the bubbling pond under lovely shade trees. Everybody happily lunched and relaxed in this bucolic setting. We are very grateful to Stan Dorman for providing this beautiful location.&#0160;&#0160; Many thanks to Graul\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Market of Hereford for providing the delicious,&#0160; bountiful&#0160; lunch! The membership committee would also like to thank Peg Perry (GVC Education and Restoration Director), GVC President Charlie Conklin, Winny Tan, Gene Flanagan and Ron Homan, and the deli department at Graul\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Market!&#0160; We can hardly wait for our next member appreciation event, so stay tuned for information in our spring newsletter! We hope to see you there! </p> <p>&#0160;</p> <p><em>Pat Novak, Membership Committee Chair</em></p></content:encoded>    <dc:creator>Gunpowder</dc:creator> <dc:date>2012-09-07T14:56:39-04:00</dc:date> <dc:date>2012-08-17T15:52:30-04:00</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/08/gvc-accomplishments-1989-2012.html"> <title>GVC Accomplishments 1989-2012</title> <link>http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/08/gvc-accomplishments-1989-2012.html</link> <description>The Gunpowder Valley Conservancy, a non-profit organization, mobilizes people and resources to care for the lands, waters and character of the Gunpowder Watershed.  </description> <content:encoded><p>The Gunpowder Valley Conservancy, a non-profit organization, mobilizes people and resources to care for the lands, waters and character of the Gunpowder Watershed.&#0160; Our emphasis is on land preservation and education &amp; restoration.&#0160; We preserve land through conservation easements and stewardship of the land via biannual monitoring visits.&#0160; Our education &amp; restoration program focuses on reforestation; stream adoption and cleanup; educational workshops, leadership trainings, and publications; and the installation of residential storm water pollution control measures such as rain barrels, rain gardens, Bay Wise landscaping, and edible landscapes. <br /> <br /></p> <p><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Accomplishments</span></p> <ul> <li>Bridging more than 16,000 total      volunteers to restore the Gunpowder Watershed</li> <li>Partnering with 85 community      organizations, businesses, churches, schools, and government agencies </li> <li>1,512 acres preserved through      conservation easements</li> <li>110 acres reforested mainly as      riparian stream buffers</li> <li>23,000 trees planted with 7,500      volunteers</li> <li>150 stream miles cleaned,      collecting 164 tons of trash with 7,500 volunteers through these programs:      MD Save Our Streams, Baltimore County Stream Watch, Project Clean Stream,      and Better Waterways</li> <li>50 streams adopted on 13 stream      miles with 62 Stream Leaders through Stream Watch Program since 2008 </li> <li>2 MD Leadership Awards received      from Save our Streams Program</li> <li>150 rain barrels distributed into      local communities</li> <li>30+ rain barrels installed by      GVC</li> <li>16 conservation landscaping      gardens installed for homeowners</li> <li>Provided Educational Outreach      at watershed conferences &amp; festivals, open houses, workshops,      trainings, and public meetings; 632 participants educated in 2011 alone</li> <li>Greening Communities like      Carney in Jennifer Branch Watershed:      3,000 homes      targeted with educational literature; held 3 community wide educational      events for 93 participants; assessed 52 yards for storm water pollution      control measures; conducted 24 community \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgreen solution\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd workshops (Rain      Barrel, Rain Garden, Stream Watch Trainings, Edible Landscapes Workshops)      for 192 participants; 100 households participated in restoration actions; 483      volunteers involved in greening project, contributing 1,564 volunteer      hours, valued at $33,157.00 of labor towards the project success!</li> <li>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdGunpowder Trails Club\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd developed      to monitor 100+ trail miles in Gunpowder       Falls State        Park</li> <li>7 Trail Maintenance /Invasive      Removal Workshops conducted in Loch Raven Reservoir, removing 450 lbs      invasive plants, planting 370 native herbaceous plants, installing 12      rolling grade dips to divert runoff, with 172 volunteers</li> <li>11,000 trees maintained with 466      volunteers on 55 acres since 2009 &#0160;&#0160;&#0160;</li> <li>Nominated Franklinville a      county historic village</li> <li>Helped facilitate the Greater      Kingsville Community Plan</li> </ul> <p>&#0160;</p></content:encoded>    <dc:creator>Gunpowder</dc:creator> <dc:date>2012-08-09T13:02:25-04:00</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/06/an-evening-at-marshy-point.html"> <title>An Evening at Marshy Point</title> <link>http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/06/an-evening-at-marshy-point.html</link> <description>an Evening at Marshy Point to benefit the Gunpowder Valley Conservancy Saturday, September 15, 2012, 5-8:30pm Join us for the 3rd annual Fundraising event to benefit the Gunpowder Valley Conservancy (GVC), Saturday, September 15, 2012, 5-8:30pm in Middle River at...</description> <content:encoded><p style="text-align: center;"><br /> <a class="asset-img-link" href="http://featherfiles.aviary.com/2012-06-14/f77694d11/d156577977654b9182baebbe049ff741_hires.png" style="display: inline;"><img alt="GVC Photo" border="0" class="asset  asset-image at-xid-6a00d83420bb4d53ef0167678502aa970b" src="http://gv.typepad.com/.a/6a00d83420bb4d53ef0167678502aa970b-800wi" title="GVC Photo" /></a></p> <p style="text-align: center;"><br />&#0160;<span style="font-size: 24pt; font-family: verdana,geneva;"><strong>an Evening at Marshy Point</strong></span></p> <p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;"><em>&#0160;to benefit the Gunpowder Valley Conservancy</em></span><br /><span style="font-size: 14pt;"><strong>&#0160;</strong><strong>Saturday, September 15, 2012, 5-8:30pm</strong></span></p> <p style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-size: 13pt;">Join us for the 3rd annual Fundraising event to benefit the Gunpowder Valley Conservancy (GVC), Saturday, September 15, 2012, 5-8:30pm in Middle River at the Marshy Point Nature Center.</span><br /><span style="font-size: 13pt;">It will be the perfect evening to welcome in the Fall with lite fare from Richardson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds Farm, wine and beer, a silent auction and live entertainment by Free Range Blue. <a href="http://www.freerangeblue.com/frb_002.htm" target="_blank" title="www.freerangeblue.com">(http://www.freerangeblue.com)</a></span><br /><span style="font-size: 13pt;">The evening will honor conservation heroes and end with dessert under the evening\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds new moon.</span></p> <p style="text-align: center;">The evening\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds proceeds benefit GVC\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds conservation and educational programs.<br />Tickets: $50 for GVC and MPNC members, $65 non-members when purchased on or before September 1.<br /><strong>After September 1, all tickets are $75.</strong></p> <p style="text-align: center;"><br />We  will have will-call at the door and a list of ticket purchasers if you  purchase your ticket(s) this week and don&#39;t receive it in the mail.</p> <p style="text-align: center;"><em>Proceeds benefit GVC\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds conservation and educational programs. <br /></em></p> <form action="https://checkout.google.com/api/checkout/v2/checkoutForm/Merchant/412798353905816" <dc:subject>Events</dc:subject> <dc:subject>Volunteers needed</dc:subject>  <dc:creator>Gunpowder</dc:creator> <dc:date>2012-06-08T12:01:19-04:00</dc:date> </item> <item rdf:about="http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/05/tree-planting-update-and-thanks-to-all.html"> <title>Tree Planting update and Thanks to all!</title> <link>http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/2012/05/tree-planting-update-and-thanks-to-all.html</link> <description>Hello Tree Stewards, Thank you all for volunteering to make a difference for the Earth Day and for future generations by planting 130 trees on 1 acre with the Gunpowder Valley Conservancy on April 21 at Loch Raven Reservoir. I...</description> <content:encoded><p><span style="font-family: Verdana; font-size: small;"> </span></p> <div style="right: auto;"><span style="color: #00b050; font-family: Verdana; font-size: medium;"><strong>Hello Tree Stewards,</strong></span></div> <div style="right: auto;"><span style="font-size: small;"> </span></div> <div style="right: auto;"><span style="font-family: Verdana; font-size: small;">Thank  you all for volunteering to make a difference for the Earth Day&#0160;and for  future generations by planting 130 trees on 1 acre with the Gunpowder  Valley Conservancy on April 21&#0160;at Loch Raven Reservoir.&#0160;&#0160; I wanted to  thank each of you for a fantastic planting.  You were all excellent  workers, enthusiastic, and great stewards of the earth.  &#0160;&#0160; </span></div> <div style="right: auto;"><span style="font-size: small;"> </span></div> <div style="right: auto;"><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="font-family: Verdana;">I want to especially thank the <strong><span style="color: #00b050;">Volunteers</span></strong> from:</span></span></div> <ul> <li><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="font-family: Verdana;">Eldersberg Roots and Shoots (Thanks Pat!)</span></span></li> <li>Conservation Core from Gunpowder Falls State Park (Thanks Christina!)</li> <li>Towson Univ. Beta Alpha Psi (Thanks Apar!)</li> </ul> <p><br /> <span style="font-size: small;"><span style="font-family: Verdana;"> Your energy, devotion, and care of the Earth are an excellent example for others and is greatly appreciated.</span></span></p> <div><span style="font-size: small;"> </span></div> <div style="right: auto;"><span style="font-family: Verdana; font-size: x-small;"><span style="font-family: Verdana; font-size: small;">Your  hard work of planting trees has helped to restore an upland native  hardwood forest right within our Loch Raven Reservoir, our drinking  water reserve.&#0160;&#0160; Your help to reforest the area will create wildlife  habitat,  filter our drinking water, provide cleaner air for us all, and  restore our native forests to full health.  You should feel proud for  making a difference for our environment and for future generations!</span></span></div> <p><span style="font-family: Verdana; font-size: x-small;"> <div> <div> <div><span style="font-size: small;"> </span></div> <div><span style="font-family: Verdana; font-size: small;">I would like to thank the <span style="color: #00b050;"><strong>Crew Chiefs:</strong></span></span></div> <div><span style="font-family: Verdana; font-size: small;"> </span></div> <div><span style="font-family: Verdana; font-size: small;">Erica  Cress, Kierran Sutherland, Rick McGehee,&#0160; Tom Ernst and Charlie  Conklin&#0160;for their leadership, time, and enthusiasm.  They each did an  excellent job setting up the site, leading the volunteers, and cleaning  up afterwards.  Thank you all.</span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;"> </span></div> <div><span style="font-family: Verdana; font-size: small;">I would also like to thank<strong> <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="color: #7030a0;">Chesapeake Bay Trust</span></span></strong> for helping to make this planting possible by providing the funding for  the event.  Through their watershed stewardship grant to the Gunpowder  Valley Conservancy we can plant 2,000 trees on 10 acres per year.  That  is fantastic! </span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;"> </span></div> <div> <div><span style="font-size: small;">I  hope you all had a fun, educational day and feel really good about  yourselves for helping to improve our environment.  Thank you again!  I  hope to see you again at future plantings.</span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;"> </span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;">&#0160;</span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;"> </span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;">Sincerely,</span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;"> </span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;">Peggy Perry</span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;">Program Director</span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;">Gunpowder Valley Conservancy</span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;"><a href="http://www.gunpowderfalls.org/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"><span style="color: #0068cf;">www.gunpowderfalls.org</span></a></span></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;">410-668-0118 </span></div> <div></div> <div><span style="font-size: small;"> <a class="asset-img-link" href="http://gv.typepad.com/.a/6a00d83420bb4d53ef016765fbd53a970b-pi" style="float: left;"><img alt="DSCF1765" border="0" class="asset  asset-image at-xid-6a00d83420bb4d53ef016765fbd53a970b image-full" src="http://gv.typepad.com/.a/6a00d83420bb4d53ef016765fbd53a970b-800wi" style="margin: 0px 5px 5px 0px;" title="DSCF1765" /></a><br /><br /></span></div> </div> </div> </div> </span></p> <p>&#0160;</p></content:encoded>    <dc:creator>Gunpowder</dc:creator> <dc:date>2012-05-01T17:31:03-04:00</dc:date> </item>   </rdf:RDF>  <!-- ph=1 -->
